EDUCATION

Dr.BuchnerSpeaksBeforeClassinEnglish
Composition—Predicts that War will
Decide the Relative Merits of German and American Systems.

Dr. Buchner, director of the
teachers' courses and head of the
department of education in the
University, delivered on last Wednesday before the advanced class
in English composition a lecture
on the subject of "Comparative
Education," which he closed with
the pertinent remark that "the
war will answer many questions
concerning the efficiency of the
educational systems of the various
belligerents." Specifically he inferred that the German system of
intensive education, which accounts for her so-called efficiency,
is now pitted against the American system of extensive education,
which finds its expression in its
democracy, and that the outcome
of the war will determine the relative value of the two systems.
Dr. Buchner's opening remark
was that education is the most expensive and far-reaching function
of government, barring only war.
It costs more and involves more
people than any other public service or institution other than war.
He maintained that organized education dates from the nineteenth
century and that education is certainly a public rather than a private function. He classified school
systems under four heads:
1. National, examples of which
are the French and Italian systems.
2. State, examples of which
are the German, American, Australian and Canadian systems.
3. County or canton, examples
of which are the Swiss and Oregon systems.
4. Local, i. e., city, township
or district.
• He then traced the development
of the European schools up to the
time of their organization in the
nineteenth century. The gymnasium of Germany, the lycee of
France and the public schools of
England first make their appearance in the sixteenth century, after the Renaissance and the Reformation; they were all characterized by the study of words and
language. They were succeeded
by the Realschule and the Realgymnasium, in which emphasis
was placed on the study of the
natural sciences. The French system was placel under national
jurisdiction by Napoleon, who also
founded the University of France
as a part of his military program.
Prior to the nineteenth century,
education enjoyed a period of freedom and liberal divisions; it is
only in the nineteenth century
that the lines between elementary,
intermediate, secondary and higher institutions become clearly
marked.
Dr. Buchner then dwelt on the
characteristics of the German system. In the first place, a distinc-

tion is made between the sexes—
boys and girls are sent to separate schools. Secondly, the destiny of boys must be determined
at the age of nine years; the parents of a boy must decide upon
his vocation so that he may be
trained accordingly. Thirdly, the
higher institutions — universities
and technical schools—are open
only to those who have gone
through prescribed and special
training, the entrance requirements are strict and limited. The
function of. the university is to
train men to become national
leaders, while the technical schools
aim ' to develop engineers. That
a premium is placed on education
is shown by the fact that university men are exempt from two of
the three years of compulsory military service. The German system
of education is directly accountable for German efficiency.
The educational systems of
France, England and the United
States were briefly sketched and
compared with the German system. The redeeming feature of
the American system is the tendency to raise the requirements
for entrance to the professions.
In concluding, Dr. Buchner
considered the social interpretation of educational values. Taking
the secondary schools as a standard of comparison, he showed that
in France there was one high
school student to 300 inhabitants;
in England, one to 202; in Germany, one to 122; and in the
United States, one to 83—making
our country the most generally
educated in the world. He finished with the significant statement that "this war will answer
many questions as to the efficiency
of the various systems"
The class in English composition, under the direction of Dr.
Powell, which has been studying
and discussing education for the
past few weeks, thoroughly apprehended Dr. Buchner's lecture.

(R. H. -WOODWARD,Jr., Captain, 1917)

Football at Johns Hopkins during the recently closed season of
1917, was the team and the game
a success and worth while, should
Hopkins have placed a formal
team on the field in view of the
present conditions at the University and throughout the country
at large?
To these very important questions there is but one answer, and
that is expressed by that small
but very significant word of three
letters, "yes." Hopkins undoubtedly made great strides this fall,
both in reputation and in developing that long cried for organization, an undergraduate team.
While winning but one game and
tying two out of nine played, the
team in every contest displayed
gameness and fight far excelling
that shown by any eleven developed at the University in many,
many years. Confronted at the
outset by lack of seasoned material, Coach Brennick put a team
of fighters on the field which made
every opponent scrap from start
to finish. And this eleven, with
the exception of two medical men
as regulars, both of whom played
the game of their own initiative
and for pure love of the sport, was
composed entirely of undergraduates, and the majority of these
under classmen! Here alone a
stride was taken which made the
game decidedly worth while to
both the University and student
body. Never before has Hopkins
been represented by a team so
preponderant in undergraduates,
in fact the "meds" have been in
the majority. If a war-time team
of undergraduates can make such
a creditable showing, surely Hopkiiis has reached that stage where
soon an entirely undergraduate
squad will represent the Black
and Blue. Let the medical men
play if they work and show the
spirit of "undergrads." This was
the .system used during the past
season, and the results obtained
show clearly that the season was
worth while,
A close study of the scores of
the games shows that only 96
points were scored by Hopkins'
opponents, an average of about 11
points per game. The Black and
Blue this year undertook the hardest and most pretensions schedule
in the history of football at Hopkins,,,and such a record is very
good indeed when it is considered
that the average age of the squad
was scarcely more than nineteen
years. It is also interesting to
note that just half of those points
were made by two teams, Brown
and Swarthmore. Was Hopkins'
gridiron reputation lowered by
such a showing? Far from dropping, it was inestimably raised in
comparison with Black and Blue
teams of some former years, teams
that played weaker opponents, yet
failed to exhibit a spirit or score

of which Hopkins might feel
proud.
In the" matter of placing a socalled "formal" team on the field,
Hopkins this year took a step in
the right direction by not hurting
the sport by "dubbing" the squad
an "informal" one. Such was the
course pursued by several of the
larger colleges, but these supposedly "informals" were 'varsity
teams in every sense of the word.
Why try and hide a feared poor
showing back of the word "informal"?
Finally, the season. was a success and should have been carried
through, even if for only one reason, that the game of football
needs and makes men of the stuff
that Uncle Sam now requires.
Quitters and mollycoddles find
no place on football teams. The
men that play the game learn to
fight for victory and give all they
have to attain that end, and this
year Hopkins showed that she had
the men and the spirit to come
through. Tile country needs Such
men and such spirit, and the college football field of America is
an ideal place to develop it. N o
matter what the time or conditions, football forms ties of friendship and fidelity which may be obtainted in no way except by conFtant work side by side, giving and
taking together, winning and losing in good spirit, and fighting
each one day by day and side by
side for the same and common
cause, the Univeesity!

communication in the field. The
course is only open to students

electrical engineering or are otherwise qualified.

consisting of work in the semaphore and wig-wag codes and with
the heliograph and night-lantern,
which was begun Tuesday, December 11, under the direct supervision of Corporals W. M. Driver

exacting requirements and bids

responsible by the commandant
for the efficiency of the signalers
in his company and can at his own
discretion recall any man who
does not show the proper interest
and appoint some one to take his
place.

very popular, especially to those
of the draft age, because the Signal Corps is one of the most important branches of the service

undoubtedly prove of great value

Mr. Kistler has now successfully launched his series of battalion dances. To those just learning this great sport at his noon
classes (held in opposition to the
Y. M. C. A. chapel) the following
hints will be of inestimable value.
They are a few of the most poullar ones:
It is very graceful to fox-trot
with the shoulders hunched up
and the head protruding forward
at the same level. The steps
should be short, only two or three
inches, and twice as fast as the
music. This is the true trotting
motion.
A popular variation of the onestep is the "stoop." The upper
part of the body should be erect,
the knees should be bent to about
ninety degrees and the left arm,
stiff, should point horizontally in
the direction of motion, holding
the partner's right hand just behind her shoulder.
"Walking the dog" is done by
(lancing with the back toward the
line of direction. The partner is
drawn ahead in jerks by the shoulders with her feet offering a slight
resistance. The overcoming of
this resistance causes the stamping, stumbling effect desired.
In the skating step, done to
fox-trot music, the couple forms
a capital "A," with the shoulders
as the apex. The steps are in
slow time, with a quick changestep at irregular intervals.
One must use tact with his partners. If one gets a girl who rests
her chin on his shoulder, he should
press his head firmly gainst her
ear. This usually makes her stop.
Here are two of the most artistic ways of holding the partner's outstretched right hand: In
the first, the palms are pressed
together, with the fingers parallel,
extended, and vertical in the second, the fingers of the partner are
held between the tip of one's index finger and the thumb, in the
manner of a hot coal or a sticky
peppermint drop.
On a crowded floor, dance backwards only in the open spaces.
When going forward, if a collision should occur, the partner
will serve as a shock absorber.
When refreshments are served,
always get enough for two couples.
One's appetite is usually by this
time quite keen, and the liberality
is seldom noticed anyway.

LECTURES ON

EDUCATION

Dr.BuchnerSpeaksBeforeClassinEnglish
Composition—Predicts that War will
Decide the Relative Merits of German and American Systems.

Dr. Buchner, director of the
teachers' courses and head of the
department of education in the
University, delivered on last Wednesday before the advanced class
in English composition a lecture
on the subject of "Comparative
Education," which he closed with
the pertinent remark that "the
war will answer many questions
concerning the efficiency of the
educational systems of the various
belligerents." Specifically he inferred that the German system of
intensive education, which accounts for her so-called efficiency,
is now pitted against the American system of extensive education,
which finds its expression in its
democracy, and that the outcome
of the war will determine the relative value of the two systems.
Dr. Buchner's opening remark
was that education is the most expensive and far-reaching function
of government, barring only war.
It costs more and involves more
people than any other public service or institution other than war.
He maintained that organized education dates from the nineteenth
century and that education is certainly a public rather than a private function. He classified school
systems under four heads:
1. National, examples of which
are the French and Italian systems.
2. State, examples of which
are the German, American, Australian and Canadian systems.
3. County or canton, examples
of which are the Swiss and Oregon systems.
4. Local, i. e., city, township
or district.
• He then traced the development
of the European schools up to the
time of their organization in the
nineteenth century. The gymnasium of Germany, the lycee of
France and the public schools of
England first make their appearance in the sixteenth century, after the Renaissance and the Reformation; they were all characterized by the study of words and
language. They were succeeded
by the Realschule and the Realgymnasium, in which emphasis
was placed on the study of the
natural sciences. The French system was placel under national
jurisdiction by Napoleon, who also
founded the University of France
as a part of his military program.
Prior to the nineteenth century,
education enjoyed a period of freedom and liberal divisions; it is
only in the nineteenth century
that the lines between elementary,
intermediate, secondary and higher institutions become clearly
marked.
Dr. Buchner then dwelt on the
characteristics of the German system. In the first place, a distinc-

tion is made between the sexes—
boys and girls are sent to separate schools. Secondly, the destiny of boys must be determined
at the age of nine years; the parents of a boy must decide upon
his vocation so that he may be
trained accordingly. Thirdly, the
higher institutions — universities
and technical schools—are open
only to those who have gone
through prescribed and special
training, the entrance requirements are strict and limited. The
function of. the university is to
train men to become national
leaders, while the technical schools
aim ' to develop engineers. That
a premium is placed on education
is shown by the fact that university men are exempt from two of
the three years of compulsory military service. The German system
of education is directly accountable for German efficiency.
The educational systems of
France, England and the United
States were briefly sketched and
compared with the German system. The redeeming feature of
the American system is the tendency to raise the requirements
for entrance to the professions.
In concluding, Dr. Buchner
considered the social interpretation of educational values. Taking
the secondary schools as a standard of comparison, he showed that
in France there was one high
school student to 300 inhabitants;
in England, one to 202; in Germany, one to 122; and in the
United States, one to 83—making
our country the most generally
educated in the world. He finished with the significant statement that "this war will answer
many questions as to the efficiency
of the various systems"
The class in English composition, under the direction of Dr.
Powell, which has been studying
and discussing education for the
past few weeks, thoroughly apprehended Dr. Buchner's lecture.

Football At Johns Hopkins, 1917. I
(R. H. -WOODWARD,Jr., Captain, 1917)

Football at Johns Hopkins during the recently closed season of
1917, was the team and the game
a success and worth while, should
Hopkins have placed a formal
team on the field in view of the
present conditions at the University and throughout the country
at large?
To these very important questions there is but one answer, and
that is expressed by that small
but very significant word of three
letters, "yes." Hopkins undoubtedly made great strides this fall,
both in reputation and in developing that long cried for organization, an undergraduate team.
While winning but one game and
tying two out of nine played, the
team in every contest displayed
gameness and fight far excelling
that shown by any eleven developed at the University in many,
many years. Confronted at the
outset by lack of seasoned material, Coach Brennick put a team
of fighters on the field which made
every opponent scrap from start
to finish. And this eleven, with
the exception of two medical men
as regulars, both of whom played
the game of their own initiative
and for pure love of the sport, was
composed entirely of undergraduates, and the majority of these
under classmen! Here alone a
stride was taken which made the
game decidedly worth while to
both the University and student
body. Never before has Hopkins
been represented by a team so
preponderant in undergraduates,
in fact the "meds" have been in
the majority. If a war-time team
of undergraduates can make such
a creditable showing, surely Hopkiiis has reached that stage where
soon an entirely undergraduate
squad will represent the Black
and Blue. Let the medical men
play if they work and show the
spirit of "undergrads." This was
the .system used during the past
season, and the results obtained
show clearly that the season was
worth while,
A close study of the scores of
the games shows that only 96
points were scored by Hopkins'
opponents, an average of about 11
points per game. The Black and
Blue this year undertook the hardest and most pretensions schedule
in the history of football at Hopkins,,,and such a record is very
good indeed when it is considered
that the average age of the squad
was scarcely more than nineteen
years. It is also interesting to
note that just half of those points
were made by two teams, Brown
and Swarthmore. Was Hopkins'
gridiron reputation lowered by
such a showing? Far from dropping, it was inestimably raised in
comparison with Black and Blue
teams of some former years, teams
that played weaker opponents, yet
failed to exhibit a spirit or score

of which Hopkins might feel
proud.
In the" matter of placing a socalled "formal" team on the field,
Hopkins this year took a step in
the right direction by not hurting
the sport by "dubbing" the squad
an "informal" one. Such was the
course pursued by several of the
larger colleges, but these supposedly "informals" were 'varsity
teams in every sense of the word.
Why try and hide a feared poor
showing back of the word "informal"?
Finally, the season. was a success and should have been carried
through, even if for only one reason, that the game of football
needs and makes men of the stuff
that Uncle Sam now requires.
Quitters and mollycoddles find
no place on football teams. The
men that play the game learn to
fight for victory and give all they
have to attain that end, and this
year Hopkins showed that she had
the men and the spirit to come
through. Tile country needs Such
men and such spirit, and the college football field of America is
an ideal place to develop it. N o
matter what the time or conditions, football forms ties of friendship and fidelity which may be obtainted in no way except by conFtant work side by side, giving and
taking together, winning and losing in good spirit, and fighting
each one day by day and side by
side for the same and common
cause, the Univeesity!

Mr. Kistler has now successfully launched his series of battalion dances. To those just learning this great sport at his noon
classes (held in opposition to the
Y. M. C. A. chapel) the following
hints will be of inestimable value.
They are a few of the most poullar ones:
It is very graceful to fox-trot
with the shoulders hunched up
and the head protruding forward
at the same level. The steps
should be short, only two or three
inches, and twice as fast as the
music. This is the true trotting
motion.
A popular variation of the onestep is the "stoop." The upper
part of the body should be erect,
the knees should be bent to about
ninety degrees and the left arm,
stiff, should point horizontally in
the direction of motion, holding
the partner's right hand just behind her shoulder.
"Walking the dog" is done by
(lancing with the back toward the
line of direction. The partner is
drawn ahead in jerks by the shoulders with her feet offering a slight
resistance. The overcoming of
this resistance causes the stamping, stumbling effect desired.
In the skating step, done to
fox-trot music, the couple forms
a capital "A," with the shoulders
as the apex. The steps are in
slow time, with a quick changestep at irregular intervals.
One must use tact with his partners. If one gets a girl who rests
her chin on his shoulder, he should
press his head firmly gainst her
ear. This usually makes her stop.
Here are two of the most artistic ways of holding the partner's outstretched right hand: In
the first, the palms are pressed
together, with the fingers parallel,
extended, and vertical in the second, the fingers of the partner are
held between the tip of one's index finger and the thumb, in the
manner of a hot coal or a sticky
peppermint drop.
On a crowded floor, dance backwards only in the open spaces.
When going forward, if a collision should occur, the partner
will serve as a shock absorber.
When refreshments are served,
always get enough for two couples.
One's appetite is usually by this
time quite keen, and the liberality
is seldom noticed anyway.

choose a proposition and develop
it argumentatively.

1918 contest is drawn from contemporary history. It is "French
Democracy Under the Test of
War." Suggested sub-topics suitable for discussion are presented

Was the French Republic Prepared?
The Republic and Its Allies.
The Capital in Danger.
The National Morale.
The French Parliament and
War Administration.
Alsace-Lorraine: History and
Sentiment.
The War and Religious Controversy.
A five-minute speech on one of
these sub-topics (or a similar
phase of the main topic) will be
adequate for the preliminary trial.
To be winner of the Tocqueville
medal is one of the highest honors
within the reach of an undergraduate at Hopkins. It is to be hoped
that this year, when the subject
is of such timely interest, the competition will be unusually spirited.
